stream_context.summary: Kaze worked primarily on the final Bowser boss fight, focusing on programming Bowser's AI, movement, and the mechanics of grabbing and throwing him. He also debugged several significant technical issues, including an object rotation bug and surface collision problems, while discussing his game design philosophies, the switch to YouTube streaming, and implementing new assets from his team.

development_findings.summary: The game has evolved significantly since the public demo, to the point where Kaze considers it an almost completely new experience.
development_findings.quote: The actual final game is so unrecognizable from the demo right now it's actually crazy.

development_findings.summary: Kaze devised a significant optimization to fix 'floor cocking' (where surfaces hide each other) by keeping the surface sorting but only checking the Y-coordinates of relevant floors, preventing unnecessary data from being loaded into the dcache.
development_findings.quote: Here's the optimization. So since we need to fix floor clacking like this, we originally had to remove the sorting priority as well. But I had the idea, what if we just keep the sorting priority, and we kill all the floors that are too high, and then we can just only iterate 0x10 bytes of each floor?

development_findings.summary: The core mechanic of the Bowser boss fight involves grabbing his tail and throwing him off the ship, with the encounter's difficulty and speed ramping up after each successful throw.
development_findings.quote: The idea here is gonna be that you have to grab bozos tail and from off the ship and he's gonna jump back to his castle once that happens. The first time has to be very easy and then it has to get faster and faster.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is willing to introduce breaking changes, such as a new animation format from Lilaa, if it leads to a permanent improvement in the game's quality.
development_findings.quote: I don't mind just breaking a bunch of stuff. It means the game is going to be better forever.

development_findings.summary: Significant changes have been made to Mario's physics to improve game feel, such as allowing the player to immediately jump again after landing from a long jump or triple jump.
development_findings.quote: One thing that really changes feel is that you can long jump out of the long jump land like this. That's a huge change to game feel. And you can jump out of like a triple jump land like this.

development_findings.summary: The team has opted to use streamed music, which offers higher quality at the cost of significantly increasing the ROM's file size, with music accounting for over 70% of the current total.
development_findings.quote: Currently, the ROM is 44.6 megabytes and 32.1 megabytes is music because we have a lot of stream to music. A stream music performs better. It sounds better, but it's giant file size wise.

development_findings.summary: Kaze uses a clever technical trick of negative scaling and face culling on mirrored background models to effectively halve their polygon count and improve performance.
development_findings.quote: I use a negative scale and I Turn on front face culling and turn off back face culling. So that way in the ship only is like about half the amount of polygons

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugged a major issue where objects held by Mario would have incorrect rotation and position, eventually tracing it to how his custom code interacted with the original game's functions for held objects.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong design philosophy against including many options in games, believing it leads to player confusion and a less unified experience. He argues that fewer choices lead to greater player satisfaction.
context_findings.quote: I hate options. I think games should give you as few options as possible, as little as you can get away with. ... There's an actual psychological experiment carried out where if you give someone the option to pick between two flavors of candy, they're going to be happy with that choice, much happier with that choice than if you give them 10 flavors to pick from.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the software development industry discourages writing highly optimized or 'good' code in favor of more accessible, simpler code that a larger, less-skilled workforce can contribute to.
context_findings.quote: You can't really write good codes because bad programmers are not gonna be able to work with good code. So really like the industry just discourages writing good code now for the reason that people do need to be able to actually work on your games.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is aware of the legal risks from Nintendo and plans to strategically delay the open-sourcing of the game's code post-release to prevent an immediate takedown.
context_findings.quote: We should probably delay open sourcing the game a little from the initial release, just so Nintendo doesn't instantly take it down.

context_findings.summary: The decision to switch streaming from Twitch to YouTube was driven by both community preference and a more favorable revenue split on YouTube.
context_findings.quote: I ran some pulse it seems that most of my community prefers my streams to be on YouTube so YouTube is what we do. ... Twitch actually only gives you a 50-50 card, which sucks. I think YouTube is 70-30. It's another good reason to switch to YouTube.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions he is saving money with Zeina to buy a house, indicating a long-term personal financial goal.
context_findings.quote: I gotta save up so we can eventually get a house.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's core value in platformer design is providing players with a sense of freedom and the ability for skill expression, which explains his focus on nuanced movement mechanics.
context_findings.quote: For me, what's really important in a platformer is that I get that sense of freedom. That sense of skill expression.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a 3D model for the tutorial bunnies, which Kaze implemented during the stream.
Kaze had to debug an issue with the tutorial bunny model having two textures instead of one, questioning the reason for the setup.

zeina.summary: Kaze jokingly refers to Zeina as his 'animation slave', highlighting a casual and playful dynamic in their working relationship.
zeina.quote: My animation slave in the background.

zeina.summary: Zeina is a key contributor for animations. Kaze notes that her involvement, along with his own practice, means they have enough animation support for the project.
zeina.quote: I can do the animations. I don't think he wants to, but don't worry. We have Zaina doing some animations. I might redo some animations. Then there is enough people doing animations now.

zeina.summary: Zeina views her animation work on the project as a positive experience that serves as good practice and helps build her professional portfolio.
zeina.quote: It's very good practice for you. Oh, yeah. And it's portfolio building and you like it. So perfect.

zeina.summary: Zeina works as a kitchen cook, a job she generally dislikes but finds tolerable due to a good team.
zeina.quote: I am currently a kitchen cook and I hate kitchens. I hate it. Actually, that's not entirely true. I have a good team to work with right now.

key_stories.title: The Held Object Rotation Bug
key_stories.summary: Kaze spent a significant portion of the stream debugging a complex visual bug where held objects were not rotating correctly with Mario. His methodical process of elimination, deep engine knowledge, and persistence eventually led him to identify and fix the faulty interaction between his custom code and the game's original logic.
key_stories.challenge: A persistent bug where objects held by Mario, like the Resnor enemy, would have incorrect rotation and position, making them unplayable.
key_stories.process: Kaze first noticed the bug with Resnor. He tried removing blocks of code to isolate the problem, suspecting it was related to recent refactors. He hypothesized it could be an issue with reading object fields, compiler optimizations, or the fundamental way his held object code interacts with vanilla functions. After a long process of trial and error, he pinpointed the faulty code segment and rewrote it to correctly copy Mario's angle to the held object.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze eventually fixed the issue by identifying and correcting how his custom object management code was interacting with the original game's code that handles held object rendering. The fix required careful refactoring to ensure Mario's and the object's angles were correctly synchronized.
key_stories.key_quote: The crazy part is that they seem to completely ignore what Mario is doing. Like entirely.

key_stories.title: The 'Floor Cocking' Optimization
key_stories.summary: Kaze detailed his elegant solution to a long-standing bug in the SM64 engine known as 'floor cocking'. Instead of a brute-force fix, he devised a clever method that not only solved the issue but also created a new performance optimization, showcasing his deep technical understanding of the game's architecture.
key_stories.challenge: The original SM64 engine has a 'floor cocking' bug where certain floor geometries can cause Mario to fall through the world. Fixing this naively would remove a performance optimization.
key_stories.process: Kaze explained that the original game sorted surfaces from highest to lowest and stopped checking after finding the first valid floor, which caused the bug. The simple fix was to remove this sorting, but that hurt performance. Kaze's breakthrough was to keep the sorting but add a preliminary check to discard floors that are too far above Mario, and then only load the Y-coordinate data (the first 0x10 bytes of the surface struct) for the remaining floors, saving a significant amount of processing time.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze implemented a solution that both fixed the 'floor cocking' bug and introduced a new, significant optimization. The game now correctly handles complex floor geometry while running more efficiently by avoiding loading unnecessary data for distant or irrelevant surfaces.
key_stories.key_quote: But I had the idea, what if we just keep the sorting priority, and we kill all the floors that are too high, and then we can just only iterate 0x10 bytes of each floor?

key_stories.title: The Switch to YouTube
key_stories.summary: Kaze made a strategic decision to move his development streams from Twitch to YouTube. The move was based on a combination of direct community feedback from polls and the superior financial incentives offered by YouTube, reflecting a blend of community engagement and business sense.
key_stories.challenge: Deciding on the primary platform for live streaming after using Twitch for a long time.
key_stories.process: Kaze conducted a test stream on YouTube to see how it went. He then ran polls within his community to gather direct feedback. After seeing a clear preference for YouTube, and considering the platform's more favorable 70/30 revenue split compared to Twitch's 50/50, he made the switch.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze has decided to permanently move his streams to YouTube, citing both community preference and a better financial revenue split as the primary drivers for the decision.
key_stories.key_quote: I ran some pulse it seems that most of my community prefers my streams to be on YouTube so YouTube is what we do.
